item.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: US Supreme Court judge dies of cancer, aged 87
item.description: The justice, an iconic champion of women's rights, dies at 87 after suffering from pancreatic cancer.

item.title: Covid-19: Lockdown in parts of Madrid amid virus spike
item.description: New restrictions in the Spanish capital come as Europe braces itself for a second wave of infections.

item.title: Thailand protests: Thousands gather for mass anti-government rally
item.description: Demonstrators are calling for the prime minister's resignation and reform of the monarchy.

item.title: Syria war: US deploys reinforcements to Syria after Russia clashes
item.description: A US official says the move sends a "signal to Russia" to avoid "provocative actions" in Syria.

item.title: Johnson considers new measures as UK cases surge
item.description: Options being looked at in England include a ban on households mixing, and early pub closures.

item.title: Brazil's Pantanal fires: Animals 'dying of hunger and thirst'
item.description: The forest fires have had a devastating impact on the wildlife of the world's largest wetland.

item.title: More Afghan interpreters eligible to settle in UK after rule change
item.description: A rule change means about 100 more of those who served with British forces will be able to live in the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: US health chiefs reverse advice on Covid-19 testing
item.description: The CDC caused controversy in August by saying that anyone without symptoms should not be tested.

item.title: Yasukuni Shrine: Japan's ex-PM Abe visits controversial memorial
item.description: Shinzo Abe, who last visited the Yasukuni Shrine in 2013, made the trip days after stepping down.

item.title: UK ministerial bodyguard 'left gun on plane'
item.description: The foreign secretary was returning to London when the incident is reported to have happened.

item.title: Danny Masterson: That ’70s Show star denies rape charges, his lawyer says
item.description: The actor's lawyer dismisses the charges as politically motivated at a court hearing in Los Angeles.

item.title: Belarus: Jailed protest leader Maxim Znak on hunger strike
item.description: The move by a top dissident comes as UN officials deplore rights abuses in Belarus.

item.title: TikTok and WeChat: US to ban app downloads in 48 hours
item.description: The ban on downloading the apps in the US takes effect on Sunday unless President Trump intervenes.

item.title: Medicane Storm Ianos lashes western Greece
item.description: Intense wind and rain flood streets and fell trees on islands in western Greece.

item.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: Obituary of the Supreme Court justice
item.description: US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a trailblazer to women of all stripes.

item.title: 'Ginsburg was an amazing woman' - Trump
item.description: President Trump said the justice 'lived an amazing life" while rival Joe Biden praised her legal legacy.

item.title: Remembering the trailblazer for women’s rights
item.description: The Supreme Court justice has died at the age of 87 after undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer.

item.title: Meet the judges on the top US court
item.description: The US Supreme Court can have a huge impact on everyday American life - do you know who the justices are?

item.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg death: How has Trump's Supreme Court changed America?
item.description: This court has been billed the most conservative in modern history. But does it vote that way?

item.title: Rock climbing when you're blind
item.description: Matthew Shifrin took up the sport almost a year ago - with the help of a friend and a childhood toy.

item.title: Coronavirus: what Israel's second lockdown feels like
item.description: Two Jerusalem residents give their thoughts to the BBC from Israel, the first country to reimpose a nationwise lockdown.

item.title: ICYMI: A thirsty armadillo and record-breaking free diver
item.description: Some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Week in pictures: 12 - 18 September 2020
item.description: A selection of remarkable images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Belarus protests: Women try to unmask those detaining protesters
item.description: Women want to hold to account the masked people picking protesters off the street in Belarus.

item.title: The racist church bombing that shocked the world
item.description: In 1963, four young black girls were killed in a racist bomb attack at a church in Alabama.

item.title: Super Mario at 35: 'The little plumber who defined a genre'
item.description: Battling Bowser, protecting Peach, what makes Mario magical as he celebrates 35 years?

item.title: What maths is involved in stirring a cup of tea?
item.description: A professor has won £2.3m for applying complex maths to simple situations - like stirring tea.

item.title: How many people does it take to oust a political leader?
item.description: How big does a protest need to be to topple a political leader? One estimate says 3.5% of the population will nearly always succeed.

item.title: Pakistan outcry over police victim-blaming of gang-raped mother
item.description: A police chief's comments spark an unprecedented backlash after a woman was raped in front of her children.

item.title: IPL 2020: The players who could become new cricket superstars
item.description: The 2020 edition of the Indian Premiere League begins on Saturday.

item.title: Coronavirus in South Africa: Relief, pride and the 'new normal'
item.description: As the "worst phase of the epidemic" is overcome, experts delve into the data to learn more about Covid-19.

item.title: Covid-19 Singapore: A ‘pandemic of inequality’ exposed
item.description: Life has returned to normal for many in Singapore, but one group of people still remain in lockdown.

item.title: Mozambique's jihadists and the 'curse' of gas and rubies
item.description: Three years into an escalating insurgency, the president admits the "resource curse" is to blame.

item.title: On the trail of stolen photographs
item.description: Some call them copyright trolls, but these companies say they defend photographers' rights.

item.title: Reed leads DeChambeau by one shot in US Open at testing Winged Foot
item.description: Patrick Reed has a slender lead over fellow American Bryson DeChambeau heading into the weekend after a high-scoring second round in New York.

item.title: Liverpool agree £45m deal for Wolves forward Jota
item.description: Liverpool agree a deal to sign Wolverhampton Wanderers forward Diogo Jota - with young Reds defender Ki-Jana Hoever moving to Molineux for up to £13.5m.

item.title: Man City's Aguero could be out for two months, says Guardiola
item.description: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola fears Sergio Aguero could miss the first two months of the Premier League season.

item.title: ‘Liverpool are getting an absolute superstar’ - what Thiago will bring to the champions
item.description: What can Liverpool expect from new signing Thiago Alcantara? How does he compare to their other midfielders?

item.title: 'Let's use our voices to grow our game' - Isa Guha column
item.description: Isa Guha, the former England bowler and now BBC cricket commentator, discusses the growth of the women's game and why the England v West Indies series is so important.

item.title: Bale arrives at Tottenham training ground to complete loan move
item.description: Real Madrid forward Gareth Bale nears a return to Tottenham after visit to the club's training ground.

item.title: The Australian family that travels 1,800km to run an outback pub
item.description: The Ellis family in Australia make frequent trips on a small plane, fulfilling what they call "a dream".

item.title: Nigeria's slave descendants prevented from marrying who they want
item.description: Campaigners fight to overturn customs and a caste system that discriminates against some Igbo people.

item.title: The coal-pots fuelling Antigua's ghost stories and folk tales
item.description: In generations past, Antiguans would gather around a coal-pot not only to cook but also to socialise.

item.title: California and Oregon 2020 wildfires in maps, graphics and images
item.description: A visual guide to the wildfires ravaging California, Oregon and other western states.

item.title: Naomi Osaka: How a shy introvert has found her voice to become tennis' new leader
item.description: The softly spoken Naomi Osaka is finding her voice to become a leader on and off the tennis court, after her second US Open title.
